lead_paragraph: In 1924, the French designer Jean-Michel Frank collaborated with Hermès on a collection of furniture, including the Confortable armchair and sofa, the elegant, cubic forms of which made it one of the most admired - and widely copied - designs of the 20th century. This month in Paris, for the inauguration of its new home division, Maison, Hermès is reintroducing these and other Frank pieces, including a straw-marquetry screen, a shagreen-covered vanity and the designer's X-base dining table. Robert Chavez, the president and C.E.O. of Hermès USA, sees ''a very exciting potential in the U.S.'' for the Jean-Michel Frank by Hermès collection, given the customer demand for furniture with the Hermès label. Previously, the company's furniture was limited to Pippa, a small collection by the architect Rena Dumas, who designed Hermès stores and who was married to Jean-Louis Dumas, the chairman of Hermès from 1978 to 2006. (Rena died in 2009, and Jean-Louis in May.) Their son, Pierre-Alexis Dumas, the company's artistic director and a sixth-generation member of the founding Hermès family, said starting Maison with historic designs was a deliberate strategy: ''We had to go backward to understand our roots and to go forward into the future.'' And in that future - April 2011, to be exact - the company will unveil further Maison collections, this time by a roster of (yet to be revealed) contemporary designers.
